title: Collisions - center of mass speed of blocks

content.question: Two blocks <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> have masses <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math>, respectively, and are free to move on a horizontal surface with negligible friction, as shown in the figure. Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is initially moving with speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> toward Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, which is at rest and has a spring attached to one side. Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> then makes contact with the spring, causing the spring to compress. After the spring reaches its maximum compression, the blocks move apart and Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> loses contact with the spring. What is the speed of the center of mass of the blocks-spring system after the blocks have separated?
